intro: Calamus myriocarpus, commonly known as the many-seed sedge, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Cyperaceae. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows in wetland environments, such as marshes and swampy areas. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered flowers that are often green or brown in color. Its fruit is a three-lobed capsule that contains numerous tiny seeds. Calamus myriocarpus plays an important role in stabilizing wetland soils and supporting local biodiversity.
